Understate: The claim may understate the impact of right-to-work laws on wages by only mentioning a 4.1 percent difference in per-capita personal incomes.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only cites one source, the Mackinac Center for Public Policy, which is a "free market" think tank known for supporting right-to-work laws.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that higher per-capita personal incomes in right-to-work states directly correlate to employees making more money.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the difference in wages, such as the impact of other economic factors or the presence of different industries in right-to-work states.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the findings of a study conducted by economists from the Economic Policy Institute, which states that wages in right-to-work states are actually 3.2 percent lower than in non-right-to-work states.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting conflicting evidence and opinions on the impact of right-to-work laws on wages and job growth.
